body:
I think you're right about that. Could you try parsing `Timestamp('2013/06')`. Since June has 30 days that will presumably fail too (It's still the 30th here so I can't test).

@jreback should `Timestamp('2013-02')` be equivalent to `Timestamp('2013/02')`?

Looks like `dateutil` uses the current day for both:

``` python
In [65]: from dateutil import parser

In [66]: parser.parse('2013-01')
Out[66]: datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 30, 0, 0)

In [67]: parser.parse('2013/01')
Out[67]: datetime.datetime(2013, 1, 30, 0, 0)

In [68]: parser.parse('2013-02')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-68-53cfc7a2bd41> in <module>()
----> 1 parser.parse('2013-02')

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser.pyc in parse(timestr, parserinfo, **kwargs)
    695         return parser(parserinfo).parse(timestr, **kwargs)
    696     else:
--> 697         return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
    698 
    699 

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser.pyc in parse(self, timestr, default, ignoretz, tzinfos, **kwargs)
    308             if value is not None:
    309                 repl[attr] = value
--> 310         ret = default.replace(**repl)
    311         if res.weekday is not None and not res.day:
    312             ret = ret+relativedelta.relativedelta(weekday=res.weekday)

ValueError: day is out of range for month

In [69]: parser.parse('2013/02')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-69-edf06e41be1f> in <module>()
----> 1 parser.parse('2013/02')

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser.pyc in parse(timestr, parserinfo, **kwargs)
    695         return parser(parserinfo).parse(timestr, **kwargs)
    696     else:
--> 697         return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
    698 
    699 

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser.pyc in parse(self, timestr, default, ignoretz, tzinfos, **kwargs)
    308             if value is not None:
    309                 repl[attr] = value
--> 310         ret = default.replace(**repl)
    311         if res.weekday is not None and not res.day:
    312             ret = ret+relativedelta.relativedelta(weekday=res.weekday)

ValueError: day is out of range for month
```

But we do

``` python
In [70]: Timestamp('2013-02')
Out[70]: Timestamp('2013-02-01 00:00:00')

In [71]: Timestamp('2013/02')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-71-4dafd0282f13> in <module>()
----> 1 Timestamp('2013/02')

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pandas/pandas/tslib.so in pandas.tslib.Timestamp.__new__ (pandas/tslib.c:5958)()

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pandas/pandas/tslib.so in pandas.tslib.convert_to_tsobject (pandas/tslib.c:15680)()

/Users/admin/Envs/pandas-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pandas/pandas/tslib.so in datetime._string_to_dts (pandas/tslib.c:52040)()

ValueError: Unable to parse 2013/02
```

@sinhrks let's see what @jreback has to say, but I think we patch this by changing the `/`s in `test_range_slice_outofbounds` to `-`s to follow the [iso 8601](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format. I am curious what the underlying issue is though. Want to do a PR?

'2013/02' looks like a date but is not ios compat so it doesn't parse and hence is passed to dateutil for parsing (which as one of its bugs uses the current day since no day is provided)

so easy enough to fix the test as you say tom

it might be reasonable to see if u can allow / in addition to '-' for a sep in the c code for the datetime parsing - not sure what if anything this would break

FWIW -- hit this one on
https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=pandas&arch=mipsel&ver=0.14.0-1&stamp=1401515396
glad that it was addressed -- will cherry pick that commit in Debian package
